qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I mainly use my phone for calling my contractor, co-workers, and family members. Sometimes the contractor calls to tell where the work site is. I also use WhatsApp to receive voice messages. In the evening, I watch YouTube videos or listen to songs.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, I share my phone with my wife and sometimes with other workers if they need to make a call. I don’t know how to say no.

qa.question: What apps and features do you frequently use?
qa.answer: I mostly use phone calls, WhatsApp, YouTube, and the camera. I use the camera only if someone asks me to take a photo of work.

qa.question: Do you read app permissions before allowing them?
qa.answer: No, I cannot read properly. I just press whatever button comes so the app opens.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app is safe to use?
qa.answer: If my co-workers or children say it is okay, then I use it. I don’t install apps by myself.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted messages, photos, or apps for privacy?
qa.answer: Yes, I delete photos when my phone becomes slow or full. I also delete messages when someone helps me.

qa.question: What do you do before giving your phone for repair?
qa.answer: I remove the SIM card. I don’t know how to delete everything, so I feel scared giving the phone for repair.

qa.question: Have you asked someone for help with phone problems?
qa.answer: Yes, I ask my children, younger workers, or go to a mobile shop. I feel shy because I don’t understand phones.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I trust my wife and children. I don’t trust strangers.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Yes, I save numbers with short names so others don’t know who they are.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: I helped another worker answer WhatsApp calls. I don’t know how to install apps.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know about these things.

qa.question: What do you do when you get warning messages on your phone?
qa.answer: I get scared and close the message. I usually show it to my children.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think the app can see those photos or numbers. I don’t know what happens after that.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, because family photos and messages are there. I worry someone may see them.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your photos or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Yes, once they opened my gallery saying storage is full. I didn’t say anything.

qa.question: Do you use a lock screen on your phone?
qa.answer: Yes, I use a pattern lock. My wife also knows it.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones?
qa.answer: I don’t know the difference. I use whatever others install.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand phone settings?
qa.answer: I ask my children or younger workers.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my children tell me not to share OTPs and not to answer unknown calls.

scenarios.Broken Phone: Before giving my phone for repair, I remove the SIM card and ask my children to check the phone if they are there.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If my wife uses my phone, I don’t mind. I check messages later.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I don’t install apps myself. I ask my children or co-workers.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I help them make calls. I don’t explain apps because I don’t understand myself.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: I only make the call I need and return it quickly.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I ask my children to delete everything before giving the phone.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I don’t know about cloud backup. If old photos come back, I will be very worried.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: I don’t use free WiFi. I only use mobile data.
scenarios.Lottery Call: I cut the call and block the number.
scenarios.Emergency Bank Transfer: I first call the person or ask my children before sending any money.
